I've always loved Daddy Longlegs. They just never gave me the creepy or even scary vibe of some spiders. (I've had many run-ins with Brown Recluse spiders and two with Black Widows though I've never been bit by them.) One autumn a Daddy Longlegs somehow made it into our home and since the missus has similar feelings towards them as I do we just let it wander freely; We called him (or her?) Gus.

He must've wandered our main floor for a good two or three months before he stopped showing up and he didn't seem to be at all shy either. Many times we'd find Gus crawling up the leg of our pants or across our laps. He didn't seem to be too keen on crawling across exposed skin, like the back of hands or arms though, as he'd stop every 4th or 5th step to clean his feelers or legs. We figured it was our skin oils.

I know no one will care, but here's an anecdote of sorts: On the shores of Lake Buchanan in Texas in the 1980s, we would climb into caves along the shoreline and find huuuuuge nests of Daddy Longlegs. You would grab handfuls of them and raise your arms. They would swarm down your body and tickle as they did. You'd watch them escape back into the shadows of the granite boulders or be eaten ferociously by the perch who always seemed to understand exactly the sort of feast on the horizon. We called it 'spider storm.'

I'm a bit frustrated that you guys didn't cover the TWO other creatures also called Daddy Longlegs, one of which is ACTUALLY a spider.
Where's I'm from, people typically refer to Pholcidae spiders as Daddy Longlegs. These are actually spiders. They have never harmed humans, but it is speculated that the rumor started because they manage to trap and kill deadly spiders in their webs. You will find black widows and brown recluse that they have killed. I could see why some people would see that and assume “they must be deadly.”
Next we have Opiliones these are the Harvestman from this video. The video does a great job of explaining them though.
Finally, we have the Crane Fly. They seem to commonly be called Daddy Longlegs in the UK, though I've heard them called that where I live in the US as well. They are a type of fly with characteristic very long legs.
So one of the reasons people say daddy longlegs are a spider, or that they can fly, or that they can or can't regrow legs is because they are three different creatures. And it blows my mind how no one talks about this, even thought all three of their wikipedia pages even address this at least somewhat!

The technical name for the bugs in the video are Harvestmen and they're not arachnids at all..
they, in fact, have ten legs and they're omnivores.
Another fun fact... in the UK, they call crane flies (otherwise known in america as mosquito hawks) Daddy longlegs.
though neither of those are spiders there IS a type of spider with that name. It's named so due to the fact that two sets of its legs are slightly longer than its other two sets.
There is a myth that states that Daddy long leg spiders are one of the most venomous spiders because it has been known to kill black widows and brown recluses, but this is false...it's simply able to attack the other spiders quicker and avoid being bitten itself cos of it's extra leg length.

Daddy long legs are arthropods ("joint foot"), but are not spiders. They are called granddaddy long-legs, harvest spiders, or harvestmen and are found on every continent except Antarctica. It is believed that there are nearly 6,500 species, 46 families, and 4 suborders world wide! That's a lot of species for a group that is very often misidentified.

So in this video I learned that more than one insect is referred to as Daddy Long Legs around the world. Did some research and found the name can be attributed to three things. Harvestmen, which is what the video is about and I found out existed today. Crane Flys, which we always referred to as Mosquito Hawks. And finally Cellar Spiders, which I've only ever heard referred to as Daddy Long Legs until today.

Harvestmen/Daddy Long Legs are probably one of the most hazard prone of all arachnids, even ticks.  A tick just latches on its food and as long as it isn't caught or squished it's fine.  For a Harvestman even dinner's a shot in the dark because they directly absorb food particles rather than digest their meal (tiny mouths).  That means that they're more prone to catching diseases and parasites in their food.
